Welcome back to the Philip Defranco show and let's just jump into it.
The first thing we have to talk about today is a story that feels like it should come from The Onion, but this is real life.
Part of me can't believe it, but then the other part goes "Yeah, sounds about right."
So Let's talk about Dr. Richard Watson who is a business professor at the
University of Georgia. He has faced criticism over a stress reduction
policy that he included in the syllabi for two of his courses. And the policy in question here was included for both his fall business
courses and Data Management and energy
Informatics. After reports came out about this there was backlash and the university of Georgia made the professor remove this policy.
But luckily, the internet is a thing and I found the actual full policy and it's amazing.
Let's go through it, shall we? It reads, "Stress Reduction Policy: Emotional reactions to stressful situations can have profound consequences
for all involved. In order to avoid such situations in this class the following
policies will apply: All tests and exams will be open book and open notes including the use of
material on your laptop. All tests and exams will be designed to be completed in half the allotted time by the majority of students.
All tests and exams will be designed to assess low-level mastery of the course
material. If in a group meeting you feel stressed by your group's dynamics you should leave the meeting
immediately, and need offer no explanation to the group members. Furthermore you can request to discontinue all further group work and your grade will be
based totally on non-group work. Only positive comments about
presentations will be given in class. Comments designed to improve future presentations will be communicated by email."
And then my personal favorite: "If you feel unduly stressed by a grade for any assessable material, or the overall course you can email the instructor
indicating what grade you think is appropriate, and it will be so changed.
No explanation is required, but it is
requested that you consider waiting 24 hours before emailing the
Instructor." Adding, "While this policy might hinder the development of group skills, and mastery of the class material, ultimately these are your responsibilities.
I will provide every opportunity for you to gain high-level mastery." Okay! We all got through that together
I know that
I try to be as fair and balanced as possible,
but I want to point out that if you agree with this policy,
get out of my classroom! Out
now! You failed the course of life. This should not be a real thing happening in the real world.

you're graded on, it's open note, open book, open
computer, the test is actually designed to only take half the time you're given

you can just hit him up and say I think I deserve an "A," and he'll give you an "A." You want to know why

but this is insanity! When I talk about how I hate in society seeing this "everyone gets a trophy"
mentality. Even with my three-Year-old I make sure he understands
what failure is, and on the outside that can sound like a horrible state, but failures make us better. My son
and I have silly little races. Maybe we're in the pool. Maybe we're just running from point a to point B.
Maybe we're playing soccer.
And I do let him win here like 50% of the time because I'm not a complete dick. When he's older
I'll make him earn every single win.
I win the other 50% of the time, because I think it's important for people to know what it is to lose; what it is
to fail. One of the first times I won a race against my son his initial reaction was to cry and to scream. Right? And that's
normal; that is what a child does. And while he was crying, Mommy and Daddy said, "You know what you do, Trey, when you lose?"
He said, "Huh?" through his sniffles,
and we said, "Try again." And the next time, he ran almost at the same speed,
he still took a wide turn, and I beat him again. He screamed again. We said, "What do you do?"
He said, "Try again." This time he ran faster. He took the inside corner like he just saw his dad
do. He won. Granted, of course, because I am an adult man
I could have beaten him, but he needs to know winning and losing. We don't get better,
we don't live more fulfilling lives when we don't know failure. Some of the most miserable people
I know are people who were born with money; never had to fight for it, Mommy and Daddy gave them everything. What's the point
of a win when there are no stakes? How do you get joy out of it when you don't know the bad?

unqualified

And then, let's talk about eSports in the Olympics. It is being reported that as early as
Paris, eSports could be added to the Olympic program. Part of the Paris Bid committee has confirmed that they will be talking to the IOC about
eSports, they're talking to eSports representatives, and part of the reason why that might be pushed through is the 2022
Asian Games. Back in April, The Olympic Council of Asia
announced that eSports will be a medal sport at the 2022 Asian games. At the Asian Games organizers are planning four events, featuring Dota2,
Starcraft 2, Hearthstone, and a sports game. While that last game has yet to be decided, they say it will be either from the NBA, or
Fifa franchise. And while by itself that is a big step towards the mainstream, it may lead to something even bigger. And the reason for
that is the Asian games are recognized by the IOC, and are billed as the world's second largest
multi-sport event after the Olympics. they have 45 national delegations, about 10,000 athletes taking part in the last games.
It's being argued by some that the IOC needs to take eSports seriously if they want to bring in a new younger audience.

However,
the IOC's President Thomas Bach, whose support is crucial to eSports being added as an Olympic event is less than
convinced about it, saying, "We are not yet 100% clear whether eSports is really a sport with regard to physical
activity, and what it needs to be considered sport." And so I'd love to pass the question on to you.
Do you think that eSports should be in the Olympics? Yes?
No? What are you thinking, because I'm personally torn on it. I think for the Olympics, from a business standpoint, it
just makes sense. Interest in the Olympics has been dropping. For the 2016 Rio games, NBC said they averaged 26 million viewers.
That was a drop of 15% viewership from the 2012 game. Meanwhile, the 2016 Dota 2 championships had a viewership of
5.7 million people. That's from just one MOBA, so from a pure business standpoint seems like it makes sense.
But of course the other arguments against it,
there's two. One, people saying it's not a real sport. To that I would say, I think you need to broaden your
definition of what you think sport is. There a lot of similarities, and it is skill-based. The other argument, and
I feel like it's a more valid argument,
is it is not a physical sport. You could also argue that it is dependent on
reflexes, critical thinking, honestly anything to make it more interesting at this point. Actually, last second idea!

Then, let's talk about this controversy and backlash coming out of Georgia. The EAV Barbell club in Atlanta,
Georgia has come under fire recently for a sign that simply showcases their policies. Like I said, it's simple. "One,
No crossfit cultism. Two, no fucking cops." -The owner's words, not mine.
The sign was also shared on the gym's Instagram page with the caption, "We simplified our membership policy. #weightlifting
#howwedo #fightthedemons #acab #resist #DaveCastroisacrimeagainsthumanity
#atl #ofcourse; too many fucking hashtags!
I don't know what it is about people in the fitness industry.
So many hashtags! Now, the owner Jim Chambers says part of the reason is the groups who work there are generally minorities,
and they're uncomfortable with the presence of law enforcement. Also saying the multi-use space serves as a gym,
but also as a community and gathering spot and meeting place for
activists. And, he calls himself a lifelong political activist, and explains that the policy decision is a political statement.
[Jim Chambers] "We wanted one space that was just a little different. It's not a, you-know,
aggressive, hetero, jock space that's dominated by cops and soldiers.
It's a place where you're safe from that, and we don't want to make police stronger so that they can hurt people more efficiently.
It's not a personal thing. You put a uniform on, and quite honestly I view that as an occupying enemy army when you put
that uniform on." As you might imagine, there were people that were angry about the policy,
but also that interview. Some who were angry sounded off on their Facebook page,
"EAV should be ashamed of how it treats the men and women who serve this county." Other writing,
"You won't allow cops and military in, yet
you appreciate your freedom. Disgusting!" others have also allegedly sent hate mail, sent death threats.
There are also people supporting the gym, one writing, "Keep up the good work
Don't let the internet cowards get you down." Another saying, "Thank you for being proactive about keeping your community safe." Another reading,
"Thank God this place doesn't allow police in. Nice to see a place where people can actually feel safe, no matter the color of
their skin." And Chambers didn't seem to understand what people were angry about, saying, "We've had an explicitly stated,
'no cop' policy since we opened, and we also don't open membership to the active members of the military."
But, he also says that there are military veterans that go to that gym. It's just that they're not active.
That's where he draws the line. Later adding, "American police are really just an entity that they serve capitalism,
and they serve white supremacy.
And that's the way we see that.
It was really just that there was the vulgarity on that sign,
and that seemed to bring it out for people." Chambers said he's planning on reposting the sign without the explicit language.
So the question becomes, 'Is this legal?' Lawyers and experts have found the policy strange,
but have said, because law enforcement officers are not a protected class under the law, only the courts can decide if the gym violated any
anti-discrimination laws. But also, I don't know if the Atlanta police department actually cares about this.
Their only comment and response to this story has been, "Were we to respond to an emergency
there, the sign would not stop us from lawfully doing our jobs. Also, an unfortunate side effect of the story is the negative attention
has been unfortunately affecting another gym. That's because this other gym has been mistaken for Chambers' gym.
People have been finding out about this story,
then going to try and find the contact
information of the gym to call them. Unfortunately, when you google East Atlanta Gym, the first listing that comes up is Village Fitness,
not EAV Barbell club. The owners even had to put a sign out front that reads, "We welcome and support our police and military."
That's the story as of right now, and I personally have to say I think it's just stupid. I mean, granted,
I am very interested in the discrimination lawsuit side of this story.
